lcInstruction.p: A step might include an example of how the step is performed or some text about the result of having successfully completed the steps.

li.p: Use <stepxmp> (step example) to contain an example.
Use <stepresult> to describe the result of the step.

lcInstruction.p: A step can contain any number of either of these elements, in any order.

step.cmd: Continue working in the file l_task_start.dita.
After the closing tag of the last <step> element, create a new <step> element, containing a <cmd> element and the text shown here.

stepxmp.pre: ...<step><cmd>When you have definitively identified a duck, make a note in your guide.</cmd> </step>...

info.xref: Video: Adding a step example in a DITA task

step.cmd: After the <cmd> element, add a <stepxmp> element.

stepxmp.pre: ...<step><cmd>When you have definitively identified a duck, make a note in your guide.</cmd> <stepxmp> </stepxmp> </step>...

step.info: The <stepxmp> element contains an example that illustrates or clarifies the step.

The element can contain text, as well as most elements involved in tagging text. Some of the most commonly used elements inside the element include the

element for body text, the element for admonitions, the element for preserving line breaks in body text, and the 

 element for preserving line breaks in code
                        samples.

step.cmd: Inside the <stepxmp> element, add the <lines> element and add content to it as shown here.

stepxmp.pre: ...<step><cmd>When you have definitively identified a duck, make a note in your guide.</cmd> <stepxmp> <lines> Ducks, [X] Harlequin [ ] Mallard [ ] Ruddy [ ] Wood </lines> </stepxmp> </step>...

stepsection.p: The <stepresult> element describes the result of the successful completion of the step.
The <stepresult> element must be the last element in a <step> element; no other elements can come after it.

step.cmd: After the closing tag of the <stepxmp> element, add a <stepresult> element.
